div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.p: THE PLANETS
Mercury is invisible at first, but it is an evening star at the end of the month.
Venus is a morning star throughout the month.
Mars is visible until 9.30 a.m. at the beginning of the month and until 1 a.m. at the end.
Jupiter rises at about 4 a.m. at the beginning of the month about 3 a.m. at the close.
Saturn rises at about midnight at first and 3 hours earlier at the end of the month.
The chief constellations in the South at 9 p.m. are Bootes (chief star, Arcturus) near the zenith and Libra at an altitude of 57 deg.

FRIDAY, JUNE 2, 1905.

div.head: EGYPT AND ABYSSINIA
div.p: The Council of Ministers on Tuesday last approved the statutes of the Bank of Abyssinia, which has been founded under the aegis of the National Bank of Egypt. The establishment of this bank under direct Anglo-Egyptian influence is an event of extreme political significance, for banks are quite as useful as missionaries as harbingers of "peaceful penetration." The official approval of the bank's statutes comes most opportunely, as in a few days' time the Abyssinian convention between the British, French, and Italian Governments will be signed. As the "Times" remarks, "the agreement thus concluded between Great Britain, France, and Italy, while safeguarding their several interests without infringing the sovereignty and independence of the Emperor Menelik, will be a boon to the commrece of the world by opening up the vast resources of Abyssinia to international trade and industry." But Abyssinia is of greater importance to us than it can ever be to France or Italy for the frontier line between the Sudan and Abyssinia is a very long one, and the richest part of Abyssinia lies in a strip along the eastern frontier of the Sudan conterminous for six hundred and thirty miles or thereabouts, and inhabited by men who, unlike their conquerors, are both industrious and prolific, and provided with the remembrance of oppression to avenge, and probably ready to seize the hand of any liberator that may present himself. Finally there is the link that binds the two countries, and always will form a political contract. Egypt, for whose prosperity we are responsible to the world, has the tap root of her existence in Central Abyssinia. It has been threatened in former centuries, but what was a vain menace in the days of Lalobala, King in the Thirteenth Century, or even later when Albuquerque, the Portuguese, gave counsel to the reigning King to cut off the spring of Egyptian fertility, might in these days of that modern Titan the engineer produce at least a grave political situation. If anyone will cast up the sum of these various forces he will see a strong family likeness between them and those in other parts of the world which have combined to bring the British into conflict with the ambitions and interests of other European Powers.

In this connection it is worth recalling the fact that when the German mission, under Dr. Rosen, was at Adis Abeba, great efforts were made by a German group to obtain a concession for a National State Bank. This concession, however, was refused, owing to the representations of our able minister, Sir John Harrington, and instead a similar concession was granted to the National Bank of Egypt. The establishment of the new bank will open a new era in Abyssinia and Anglo Egyptian relations, and a great feature lies before the bank. Abyssinia only needs capita for its development, and cannot truly be independent if any other European Power exercises a predominant control over the machinery that supplies the motive power of material advance.

div.head: THE NAVAL BATTLE.
DESCRIPTION OF FIGHT.
ADMIRAL FOELKERSHAM KILLED.
6,000 RUSSIANS DROWNED.
div.p: London, June 1.

The correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" with the Japanese Fleet reports from Tokio that as the Russians steamed up the Bashie Channel the Japanese vessels, which were so disposed as to enfilade them simultaneously from the front and both flanks, maintained the same position as the Russians moved north.

The fire was terrible : the Russians at first returned shot for shot, but at two o'clock the increasing confusion showed that they were practically defeated. Between three and five a cruiser of the "Admiral Nakimoff" class and the "Kamchatka" foundered, and the Russian line broke in utter disorder. The Japanese then closed up, dividing the Russians into a number of detached squadrons and pressing them towards the Nagoto coast.

When night arrived swarms of destroyer and torpedo-boats were let loose, and the battleships and cruisers also kept up a merciless fire. The night's work resulted in the sinking of the "Imperator Alexander III.," "Oslyabya," "Navarin," "Ural," and three gunboats.
With dawn the Japanese came still closer and the battle raged with unabated fury during the whole day. Here the message breaks off.
(Reuter.)

div.head: TOTAL JAPANESE LOSSES
div.p: Tokio, June 1.

Admiral Togo reports that the total Japanese losses are under 800. The battleship "Sissoi Veliki," the cruiser "Admiral Nakimoff," and the "Monomach" sank on Sunday morning while they were drifting helplessly near Tsu-Shima. The Japanese cruisers and coast vessels rescued 1,000 men.

It is estimated that there were ten thousand men on board the sunken vessels of the Baltic Squadron, four thousand of whom have been rescued, but it is feared that most of the remainder have perished. Many bodies are being washed ashore. Admiral Foelkersahm was killed on the 27th inst. in the conning-tower of the "Oslyabya," while directing the squadron.
(Reuter.)

div.head: JAPANESE LOSSES IN SHIPS.
div.p: Tokio, June 1.

The necessity for secrecy no longer existing, the Admiralty acknowledges the following losses : the battleship "Yashima," which touched a mine oon the 15th May, 1904, the destroyer "Akatsuki," on the 17th May, the gunboat "Oshima," on the same date, the destroyer "Hayatory," on the 3rd September, the gunboat "Atago," on the 6th November, and the protected cruiser "Takassago," on the 12th December.

div.head: WOUNDED AT VLADIVOSTOK
div.p: Vladivostok, June 1.
The cruisers "Oleg" and "Izumrud" have arrived.
St. Petersburg, June 1.
The Russian cruiser "Izumrud" arrived at Vladivostok with 20 wounded on board.

div.head: MOROCCO AND FRANCE
FRENCH PROPOSALS UNACCEPTABLE
div.p: Tangier, June 1.
The Sultan has informed M. Taillandier that if any reforms be introduced, it should be with the consent of the Powers. He will ask the views of each Power with reference to a conference. (Reuter.)

div.head: PARIS BOMB OUTRAGE. REGARDED CHEERILY BY KING.
div.p: Paris, June 1.
King Alfonso regards the bomb outrage cheerily, and is the object of much sympathy. There is great indignation here and at Madrid.
It is believed that the outrage was planned at Barcelona (Reuter.
Paris, June 1.
King Alfonso and M. Loubet were greatly cheered on their way back from the Chalons parade ground.

The bomb yesterday injured ten persons. One horse was killed and six were injured. The police have arrested one of the instigators. The Rome and Athens Parliaments have congratulated the King and M. Loubet. (H.)

div.head: THE COTTON WORM
div.p: has reappeared at Zankaloue, in the Zagazig district.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MALL
div.p: will close at the G.P.Q., Alexandria, at 8:30 a.m. on Monday.

div.head: QUARANTINE
div.p: restrictions as against plague arrivals from Aden have been removed.

div.head: HASSEINIEH SCHOOL.
div.p: New premises for the Hasseinieh School are to be constructed at a cost of £15,000.

div.head: New Bank.
div.p: -- According to the “Economiste d Orient; the Ionian Bank proposes to open one or two branches in Egypt.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LIBRARY.
div.p: -- From July 1 till the end of September the reading rooms of the Khedivial Library, Cairo, will be open from 5 a.m. to 1 p.m.

div.head: TANTAH LOCAL COMMISSION.
div.p: -- It is proposed to convert the Tantah Local Commission into a mixed commission, like those of Mansourah and the Fayoum.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a recovery at Toukh and two cases (one fatal) at Damanhoar, where a patient died in hospital.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: —Mr. S. Conegliano,the proprietor of the Alhambra Theatre, has opened a ten years lease of the theatre with Mr. G.B. Alderson.

div.head: P.W.D.
div.p: — Colonel Friend, RE, has been attached to Mr. Perry, Under Secretary of State for Public Works, at a salary of L.E.1,000 per annum.

div.head: THE Captain's watch.
div.p: —Captain McMillan Thomas, captain of a steamer in Alexandria harbour, had a gold watch stolen from his cabin yesterday..

div.head: HELOUAN Railway.
div.p: —The Delta Light Railway Company has informed the Ministry of Public Works that its board has voted a sum of L.E. 60,000 for the improvement of the Helouan line. f

div.head: A LADY GOVERNMENT CLERK.
div.p: —The Prisons Department has appointed El Sit Estifan as a clerk in the female prison at Cairo. She is said to be the only woman holding a clerkship in the Egyptian government.

div.head: FATAL ACCIDENT.
div.p: -- Yesterday afternoon, a coal heaver, of the name of Ibrahim Abd el Rabbs, was run over by a train on the Alexandria quays and expired on reaching hospital.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: —On the 29th and 30th May 18 vessels passed through the Canal, of which 13 were British, 1 Dutch, 1 Norwegian, 2 German, 1 Austrian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 302,931.68, making the total from the 1st May frs. 9,004,001.03.

div.head: IRRIGATION INSPECTOR'S CLOTHES STOLEN.
div.p: -- A Cairo contemporary states that while Mr. J.B. Ireland, Inspector of the Fourth Circle of Irrigation, was asleep in the Irrigation Department's rest house at Maghagha a few days ago, his clothes were stolen. The thief has not yet been discovered.

div.head: PORT SAID'S CATHOLIC SEAMEN'S CLUB.
div.p: -- The Hon. Mrs. Fraser and other well-known workers are organising a concert in Chelsea Town Hall in aid of the Catholic Seamen's Club at Port Said. This institution is largely supported from England by Roman Catholics interested in the work for seamen.

div.head: GATTI'S CIRCUS.
div.p: —Our readers will remember the theater fire at Alexandria, and the consequent destruction of the material and effects belonging to Gatti's circus troupe. Mr. Gatti, who is in Cairo with his company, now informs us that he has reconstructed the whole of the material destroyed, and, before quitting Egypt, intends giving a few performances at Alexandria in the Pyramids Theatre, beginning next week. New artistes have been engaged and are due to arrive from Europe on Sunday next.

div.head: HOTEL BEAU-RIVAGE.
div.p: -- The management of the Hotel Beau-Rivage deserves to be heartily congratulated on the success of its ball last night. This beautiful Ramieh hotel looked its best and the ball was attended by the "creme de la creme" of Alexandria and Ramieh Society. Dancing was indulged in to the strains of the band of the Royal Berkshire Regiment. The evening was a great success and Mr. Runckewitz, the new proprietor of the hotel, left nothing undone to promote the pleasure of his numerous guests. We are pleased to announce that this is the first but by no means the last of the dances to be given at his hotel during the summer season.

div.head: PORT SAID DEVELOPMENT
div.p: GREAT ACTIVITY IN HARBOUR.
PORT SAID DEVELOPMENT.
Port Said, Thursday.
Port Said harbour just now presents a busy scene. Work is proceeding apace on the im provements which are to be carried cut and on which upwards of 1,700 men are employed.

The present coal basin, which easily accommodates 16 vessels, is to be converted into a cargo loading basin for Egyptian produce, which will arrive there direct by the new Matarieh Canal or by the new line off railway now under construction. It is to be fitted with jetties and will accommodate 13 ships.

Immediately opposite this, where the petroleum basin is situated, a large space capable of holding 20 colliers is being dredged out, as is also the intervening land between it and the coal yard channel, by which means coal lighters will go direct to the yards, without, as at present, going into the main harbour. The new petroleum basin will be at the extreme end of this space.

At the back of the "Chantier des Blocs" works and sheds are being built and this space will in two years’ time be the Canal Company's ateliers, and the floating dock is to be placed close by. The old atelier will be dredged out and is to be used for local craft, for which the Basin Cherif is far too small owing to the growing local traffic.
Sheds are on the plans all along the new basins and a large piece of land between the railway and collier bay has been reserved for offices and warehouses.

At present some 150 to 200 tons of cotton are shipped here per week, but it is quite probable that with the unrivalled opportunities shippers have here to despatch their goods practically anywhere, the trade will greatly increase.

The sum allowed in the Budget for "improvements" in Port-Said harbour is £700,000, to be expended in a period of 10 years, and out of which hire of dredging plant is to be paid, together with all special contracts.

div.head: RAILWAY TRAFFIC
div.p: The railway is doing well and there seems to be little reason to doubt that the net receipts will amply suffice to pay the annuity due to the company, which will be from L.E. 16,000 to LE. 18,000 a year. There has been a notable increase in the number of passengers. During the last six months of 1902, the receipts from passenger traffic were L.E. 6,019 ; in 1903—when the change of gauge had been partially effected--the receipts for the corresponding period rose to L.E. 10,730 , in 1904, they were L.E. 13,737. It is to be observed that the heaviest passenger traffic is during the first half of the year.

The receipts from goods traffic during the first six mouths of 1902 were L.E. 1,876 in 1903, L.E. 2,037 ; in 1904, L.E. 5,139. It was only during the last two months of 1904 that the goods traffic began to develop seriously. It is expected to increase largely during the current year.

div.head: TURKISH TROOPS FROM YEMEN
div.p: The Austrian Lloyd S.S. "Gisela," which was here yesterday on a voyage from Calcutta to Austria, had on board 105 Turkish soldiers, all of Syrian origin. It appears from their accounts that they formed a portion of the garrison of Sanna when it was taken by the insurgents. After the taking of the town, the insurgents murdered the garrison officers and set free the hundred men above mentioned. Those who survived the terrible march arrived at Aden, where they were cared for by the British authorities, who sent them on here. The men yesterday started to walk along the coast of the Bay of Pelusium expecting to reach Gaza, to which district several belong in a week 's time.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF BRITISH CRUISER
div.p: The British 2nd class cruiser "Thetis” arrived at Suez early this morning. She is one of the older type, having been built in 1890, is of 3,400 tons displacement, and still steams 20 knots. She will stay here 24 hours coaling.

div.head: THE ORIENT LINE
div.p: The Orient Line S.S. "Orontes" arrived at 6 a.m. to day from Naples. She is the first vessel of the line to arrive up to time since the new “white labour " contract with the Australian Government. I believe she has had the same difficulty as have the other ships with stokers and their drinking propensities in every port.

div.head: OBITUARY. ALEC HOLMES.
div.p: It will come as a great shock to the many friends of Mr. Alec Holmes, Inspector of the Salt and Soda Company, to learn that be succumbed early on Wednesday morning to an attack of pleurisy, from which be had been suffering for but a short time. Up to Tuesday evening hope had been entertained of bis recovery, but towards night a change for the worse set in, and he passed quietly away just as dawn was breaking. Mr. Holmes was greatly liked by all who knew him, and his loss will be keenly felt by his numerous friends and by the company to whom his services were devot ed. The funeral took place at Tantah on Wednesday afternoon and was largely attended.

A Tantah correspondent writes: -The death of Mr. Holmes has cast a gloom over the British colony at Tantah, of which he was one of the most popular members. Few English-men in Egypt were more liked than Mr. Holmes and his geniality, open-hearted hospitality, and entertaining conversation made his house at Tantah one of the most pleasant spots in Egypt.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE VATICAN. QUESTION OF LOCAL HIERARCHY.
div.p: London contemporary states that by a scheme now under consideration at the Vatican, Egypt is to be withdrawn from the cate-gory of Roman Catholic missions and a regular hierarchy established here, the episcopate being drawn chiefly from British subjects.

On making enquiries at Archbishop’s House this morning we were informed that nothing was known there regarding the scheme. Some eleven years ago the question of the establishment of a regular hierarchy in this country was raised, but the project fell through, for several reasons, one of which was the comparatively restricted number of Roman Catholics in Egypt. While nothing official has reached the local ecclesiastical authorities, however, it is thought quite probable that the question may be on the tapis again at the Vatican.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive, after his visit to England, will proceed to Paris and then to Switzerland for his usual stay at Divonne.
Brewster Bey, English Secretary to the Khedive, is leaving Alexandria on Thursday next by the Florio Rubattino steamer for Naples, whence he will proceed to Paris to rejoin his Highness.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The Legislative Council met yesterday and passed the regulations concerning dogs and rabies, as well as the draft decree for the extension to all lands in Egypt of the prohibition to irrigate sharaki lands.
The regulations concerning Marsa Matrouh were withdrawn by the Government.
The Council adjourned to another sitting the examination of the modifications to be introduced in the Recruiting Law as regards the examinations of "fikis.''

div.head: THE FIKI QUESTION
div.p: The sheikh of Al Azhar University has handed to the Regent a protest regarding the modifications to be introduced in the recruiting of “fikis.” The sheikh maintains in his note that the “fikis” should be exempted from military service by reason of the fact that they give instruction in the Koran, and that, therefore, the Ministry of Public Instruction should not require of them knowledge of mathematics and other sciences.

The fiki question in Egypt is a very pressing social problem, especially in regard to the kuttabs. The term ‘fiki’ should properly be applied only to a person learned in “fiqh" (Mohamedan law), but in Egypt the term is used to denote a person who is able to recite the whole of the Koran and obtains his livelihood thereby. The attractions of a fiki's career have a very bad influence on the kuttabs and tend to divert the children of the poor from their natural avocations in the fields, or in the family workshops, and to embark them upon a career generally lapsing into mendicancy. The children flock to the "kuttabs,” not to receive instruction which will fit them for their position in life, but to commit to memory the whole of the Koran, and thereby, as reputed “fikis,” to escape from liability to military conscription. And, in Egypt, a "fiki," unless he be attached as reader to a “kuttab,” and, except for casual employment in reciting the Koran at funerals and festivals, is virtually a beggar. According to the census of 1897, there were 107,700 craftsmen of various sorts carpenters, blacksmiths, tailors, shoemakers. &c.— in Lower Egypt. The number of “fikis,” who were mostly mendicants, was no less than 100,000. It has been suggested that the qualification for exemption from military service should only be allowed to such “fikis” as have received a certain amount of education. It may be men tioned that to gain a livelihood by reciting the Koran at funerals and festivals is forbidden by the Mohamedan religion. In a report recently presented by the Grand Mufti to the Legis lative Council, and approved by that body, the practice of committing the Koran to memory was commended, but with the proviso that “the object of the study is for religious and moral guidance, and not for the very base em ployment of gaining a living thereby, or reciting at festivals or funerals, since these practices are amongst the most reprehensible of the things forbidden in Moslem law, and it is not lawful for any one to assist any efforts made with that object.”

div.head: TREMENDOUS EXPLOSION. 16 TONS OF DYNAMITE BLOWN UP AT ABOUKIR.
div.p: A record has been made at Aboukir in the history of explosives, the biggest submarine explosion that has ever taken place having occurred there yesterday, when 16 1/2 tons of the most powerful dynamite, consisting of 10 tons of blasting gelatine and 6 1/2 tons of gelignite, went off. Blasting gelatine contains 92 per cent of nitro-glycerine, which is the most powerful explosive in the world.

The explosives arrived in Alexandria some time ago and were despatched to Cairo by canal. Unfortunately, the boat in which they were being conveyed, got wrecked in a col lision, and the explosive were landed on the banks of the Mahmoudieh, but owing to the great danger which Alexandria ran from their proximity, they were removed to a fort at Aboukir and there stored.

Meanwhile, a lawsuit was bought in the Mixed Courts at Alexandria in reference to the collision and the Court decided that the explosives must be made away with. The owners, Messrs. Nobel & Co., of Glasgow, therefore undertook to destroy them, and on Wednesday afternoon Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, Sagh. Kelham, and Bimbashi Edgeworth went to Aboukir to make arrangements for the public security. The Egyptian Ministry of War was represented by Bimbashi Edgeworth.

The explosives were in a dangerous state, as owing to the action of the water in the Mahmou dieh Canal, gases had comes into operation, and if the dynamite bad been kept an explo sion might have ensued with consequences too terrible to contemplate as it is estimated that the 16 1/2 tons were more than sufficient to lay
ALL ALEXANDRIA IN RUINS !

The cases containing the explosives were transported 0n Wednesday afternoon from the fort to the seashore. There they were put into boats and carried 500 yards from the shore in the direction of Nelson's Island, where they were thrown into 15 feet of water. Electric wires were laid down from the coastguard fort to the submerged explosives and an electric battery was installed in the fort. By 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening all was ready for the explosion. At that hour, however, it was too dark to see if any fishing or other boats were in the neighbourhood for the danger zone extended to a distance of three miles.

It was therefore decided to leave the explosives in the sea until the morrow. Yesterday morning all preparations were completed under the direction of Mr. Harold Harris, F.C.S., chemist and instructor to Messrs. Nobel. He was assisted by M. Ferdinand Muguier, pharmaceutical chemist of the Ecole Superieure of Paris and technical chemical expert to the Mixed Tribunals. At 10.40 a.m. yesterday the button of the electric battery was pressed and the largest amount of dynamite ever exploded at one time went off.
A RECORD EXPLOSION.

Something like an earthquake ensued and all the houses in Aboukir were shaken, while the detonation was heard at Montazah. The sight itself was magnificent The calm blue sea suddenly became a mighty whirl of seething water, while a waterspout about 2,000 feet in height rose to the heavens. The waterspout had a base of about 200 feet in diameter and it ascended in the shape of a snow-white column of glittering foam, which remained in the air for about two minutes, and enabled some local photographers to take some snap shots.

The few spectators of the scene declare that the sight was one of unparalleled splendour, for the sun made the waterspout shine like silver. As the water was falling the sea suddenly presented quite another aspect. A huge wave rose up, many metres high, and advanced majestically but with a peculiar slowness to — wards the shore, but before it reached the land this mass of water subsided suddenly and broke up into innumerable large waves. All round the wave and long after it had sub-sided the sea presented the appearance of water boiling in a cauldron and an immense superficies of the water in the bay was churned up like boiling coffee, for it became quite brown in colour, as evidently a huge chasm was blown in the bed of the sea.
Thousands of fish were killed by the shock and their dead bodies afforded a fine haul for the local fishermen.
Mr. Harris was warmly congratulated on the success of the operation by all present, for no damage whatsoever was done owing to the very careful precautions takes by the police and the coastguards
The explosives, which were valued at £3,000, were originally consigned to Messrs Thos (Cook and Son (Egypt), Limited, Messrs. Nobel's agents in Egypt.
Mr. Harris declared that the explosion was the biggest that had ever taken place and constituted a world's record in the history of submarine explosions.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: (From our financial correspondent.)
London, May 26.

Since our last, little of importance has taken place in our stock markets here. The tone has hinged largely on the state of the market for American Rails, the continued fall in these securities having caused a good deal of uneasiness in financial circles both in London and on the Continent. Consequently this has had the effect of checking fresh business. The fact that the weak Bull element has in a great measure been cleared out accounts for the improved tendency and the disposition to a recovery in prices at the time of writing.

The hanging fire of the great land and sea battles, which are anxiously awaited, keeps up a feeling of uncertainty, especially in the foreign market The market for Egyptian securities, although somewhat inactive, continues to hold a firm position. Prices show little or no change from those ruling a week ago. The new issue of the National Bank shares, 50,000 at £10, have naturally been taken up by the present shareholders on the terms offered, namely, £20 per share, the proportion being one new share for every five old shares. The dividend will be payable on these shares in January next, and they are already being dealt in at a premium of £5 to £6 on the issue price. The old shares remain unchanged at 27 3/8. The mining shares in the Egyptian section are neglected at recent levels. The general feeling amongst the dealers is one of expectancy, awaiting developments from the mining centres.

Much comment has been made of late in the financial press as to the frequent appearance of new Egyptian land companies, and the pessimists are beginning to prophesy all sorts of dire results. We have seen it stated in one paper that the value of land in Cairo is approaching to that of land in London. To show how far this is from the mark, 1 may mention that £10 a square metre, which is the price for good land in Cairo, is equal to £42,000 per feddan. The City of London has recently let, on an 80 years' building lease, land near, but not on, one of the main thorough fares in the city, in a cul-de-sac, which, capitalised on a low valuation, works out at the rate of over £400,000 per acre for the freehold, thus showing that land in the City of London is only ten times more valuable than land in Cairo and this for some of the cheaper land in the city. It would therefore seem that the new companies which have been started to do business in Egypt ought to have a very good future if they con duct their concerns on sound principles, and get ready to obtain the benefit of the present growing demand for house property in Egypt, and the pessimists may have to wait a long time yet before their croakings become necessary.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: The engineer in charge reports: —The Roman well inside the Deir was tubed to a depth of 84'4‘ when the original bottom was appa-rently reached. The water supply had percept ibly increased, but drilling was continued and at 89’ a bed of hard white sandstone was entered and passed at 105'6" to hard black clay. In drilling the sandstone the water supply increased constantly and now stands about 2 below the level of the Deir land. 1 estimate that when about 25' of tube is out off and the old brick well cleaned to about 30' a well will be obtained capable of supplying by means of sakiehs at least 100 galls. per minute when lifted 12'—15'. The result is most satisfactory and presents the remarkable feature of a big supply standing at a level of 133' above the surface of the ground at No. 1 site distant only 6 miles. .The chemist is hard at work and some new alums have been located.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit---within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: PIGEON SHOOTING.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—Surely the decision of the A. S. C. Committee to allow a pigeon-shooting ground to be established at the club precincts is not irrevocable. The erection of such an adjunct to the pleasant, verdant calm of the grounds would be a decided blow to the popularity of the club. The peace of the place would be gone in the constant banging of the guns, not to mention the sight (which experience of such places leads one to believe would happen in this case also) of maimed, fluttering, and bleeding birds felling on to the tennis grounds and golf links.

I may be lacking in "sporting” instincts, but the element of chance for the bird being so small, and the ease and safety of the man with the gun so assured, makes this form of amusement seem to me at best but a poor game. Still it has its devotees, who already possess more than one shooting ground, which might be imagined sufficient for their delectation.—Yours truly,

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING
div.p: On Friday, 19th May, the last spoon competition for the season took place at Tourah. The spoon was won by Mr. Craig with 34+ 34+33=101. Mr. D. McDonald was second with 35 + 28 + 30=93.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
(Communication Officielle.)
div.p: La Commission Municipale s'est reunie le 31 mai 1905 a 4 h. p.m. au palais municipal sous la presidence de S.E. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky.
Séance de renvoi.

Presents : M.M. Amb. A. Ralli, vice-president, Ahmed Bey Eyoub, Hussein Bey Riaz, A. Cumbo, L. Escoffier, P. Fenderl, E. W. P. Foster, Mansour Bey Youssef, Baron A. de Menasce, Mohamed Mahfouz Bey, A. Padoa Bey, Dr. Schiess Bey, Soliman Bey Abani, T. Suzzarini, G. Zervudachi, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secretaire.
Le proces-verbal de la séance de la Commission Municipale du 29 mars 1905 est adopte.
Mention est faite de l'envoi a tous les membres des proces-verbaux de la Delegation de 2 et 9 mai 1905.

Quelques observations sont faites par M. Escoffier au sujet de certaines adjudications de fourniture de pierres ainsi qu'an sujet de la question de l'arrosage des berjes du canal Mahmoudieh et de la possibilite de profiter des installations qui seront faites par la Municipalite pour la fourniture d l'eau aux proprietes riveraines.
Ces questions sont renvoyees a l'etude de l'administration.

Le vice-president propose qu'avant d'entamer l'ordre du jour, la Commission adresse ses remerciemenets et ses felicitations aux membres du sous-comite des fetes du centenaire de Mehemet Aly pour le succes et la bonne organisation tant de la ceremonie officielle que des illuminations feeriques executees dans la soireee.
La Commission s'associe aux sentiments exprimes par le vice-president.

M. de Menasce, en son nom et en celui de MM. Yehia Bey et Zervudachi, remercie l'assemblee et dit qu'en la circonstance ils n'ont fait que leur devoir. Il saisit cette occasion pour dire quelle grande part ont eu dans le succes de ces fetes les concours precieux que le sous-comite a trouve en dehors de la Commission. L'ordre qui a regne dans lese ceremonies malgre l'affluence extraordinaire du public est du a la vigilance du commandant de la police et de ses collaborateurs ; l'eclat et le gout parfait des illuminations sont l'oeuvre du distingue directeur de la Compagnie du Gaz et la bonne organisation des corteges des eleves des ecoles qui ont ete un des attraits de la fete reveiennent a un des representants de la presse locale. 1aquelle tout entiere a prete son concours le plus utile au comite. Les remerciements qu'en cette circonstance la Municipalite adresse a tous ces collaborateurs vont egalement a tous ceux qui repondant a son appel ont pris part a ces fetes ou y ont contribue, ainsi qu'a la population entiere qui une fois de plus, dans la manifestation de son loyalisme, s'est montree digne de son bon renom.

Au nom de Yehia Bey, president du sous-comite retenu au Caire, M. de Menasce propse que la couronne en argent faite en commemoration du centenaire soit deposee sur le tombeau de Mehemet Aly, a la citadelle du Caire.
L'assemblee approuve cette proposition.

La Commission prend connaissance d'une lettre du 6 mai de S.E. le Ministre d l'Interieur informant que la Gouvernement a accepte la demande de la Municipalite tendant a confier a cette administration la totalite du service des etablissements insalubres et a lui reconnaitre en meme temps le droit de delivrer les roksas afferentes a es etablissements.
Le vice-president informe que la Delegation a'occupe des details d'organisation que comporte ce transfert.

Communication est donne d'une lettre du 11 mai de S.E. le Ministre d'Interieur portant certaines modifications au projet d'arrete sur la taxe des voitures et betes de somme, en ce qui concerue la date d'application qui est reportee au 1er janvier 1906 et le mode de recouvrement pour lequel le Ministre estime qu'il est inutile de mentionner une disposition, celle-ci etant deja prevue par l'arrete du 23 mai 1895.
La Commission arrete en consequence le projet d'arrete, qui sera soumis a la sanction du Conseil des Ministres.

Lecture est ensuite donnee d'une lettre du 14 mai 1905 de S.E. le Ministre de l'Interieur informant qu'il partage l'avis de la Commission en ce qui concerne la publication dans les journaux locaus des avis relatifs a la destruction des chiens errants.

S.E. le Ministre ajoute que la Municipalite n'aura pas a abroger son reglement lorsque celui d l'Etat aura ete promulgue mais simplement a y apporter les modifications que comparteraient les mesures plus strictes que le reglement de l'Etat pourrait contenir.

Le vice-president dit qu'en raison d l'urgence, la Delegation a demande la publication de l'arrete au "Journal Officiel", etant donne que les vues du Gouvernement sons conformes avec celles de la Commission.

Lectures est egalement donne d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre du 15 mai 1905 informant que deferant au desir de la Municipalite des instructions seront donnees au Gouvernorat d'Alexandria d'avoir a mettre en contravention les personnes qui introduiront a Alexandrie de la viande d'animaux aux abattoirs de l'interieur du pays.
La Commission en prend note.
Par lettre du 20 mai 1905 S.E. le Ministre de l'Interieur informe qu'il autorise, a titre exceptionnel, le paiement a Mme Vve Amic Bey de l'allocation de 30 L.E. votee par la Commission.

Communication est ensuite donnee d'une lettre du 30 mai de S.E. le Ministre de l'Interieur approuvant le projet de reglement pour la vente des terrains de la Municipalite, sauf certaines modifications concernant les ventes faites par la ville a l'Etat.
La Commission adopts ces modifications et arrete en consequence son reglement.

Sure le rapport du Comite du Contentieux, la Commission maintient les amendes infligees a certains fournisseurs ou entrepreneurs pour retards apportes dans la livraison de leur fourniture ou l'execution des travaux a eux confies.
L'ordre du jour appelle la discussion sur le projet de reglement interieur elabore par le Comite de reorganisation.
Ce projet est adopte avec certaines modifications.
La Commission, sur le rapport de la Delegation approuve le mode d'execution propose pour l'installation d'une conduite d'eau filtree a Ramleh.

La fourniture des tuyaux sera mise en adjudication et la pose de la canalisation sera executee en regie par la Compagnie des Eaux, sous le controle de la Municipalite, laquelle intervient pour les trois quarts dans la depense conformement aux conventions en vigueur.

Sur la proposition de la Delegation, la Commission ouvre un credit supplementaire de L.E. 200 pour less allocations accordees a titre de secours aux familles d'employes decedes et autres, a prelever sur la reserve du budget ordinaire.
Deux depenses de 60 L.E. et 68 L.E. respectivement pour transaction dans une affaire Celi et condamnation dans une affaire Caralambo sont prelevees sur le budget ordinaire.
La Commission autorise l'Administration a ester en Justice dans diverses affaires judiciaires.
Elle nomme, au scrutin secret, MM. le Dr Schiess Bey et Ahmed Bey Eyoub, comme membres provisoires de la Delegation, pendant l'absence en conge de certains membres de ce college.
La Commission approuve le projet d'echange de terrains entre la Municipalite et le Gouvernement sur les quais.
La séance est levee a 7 h. ½ p.m.

div.head: Societe Ernesto Rossi
div.p: La Societe Philodramatique "Ernesto Rossi" a donne avaut-hier dans la salle du Conservatoire Populaire de Musique une excellente soiree reqreative.

Les pieces inscrites au programme : "Una aventura di Viaggio," petite comedie en 1 acte, "Contrasto d'affetti," scenes intimes eu 1 acte, "La Vedova delle Camelie," et enfiu la jolie comedie de Scribe "Il CUoco e il Segretario," ont ete jouvees avec un brio remarquable et ont obtenu le plus legitime succes.
Parmi les acteurs, qui d'ailleurs meritent tous des eloges, qu'on nous permette de signaler MM. Musarelli et del Lucchese et parmi les charmantes actrices Mmes Brunone, Righi et Scalpellini.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marche a presente ce matin beaucoup d'animation sur toute la ligne, mais en particulier en Agricole, Banque Nationale, Salt and Soda et Estates.
Le cours de ces dernieres valeurs hausse d'une facon sensible et progressive : la Nationale de 27 7/8 a 28, l'Agricole de 13 11/16 a 14, la Salt and Soda de 34 a 35 et les Estates de 29/32 a £1.
De 1 11/16 l'Investment monte egalement a 1 13/16 vendeurs et la Land Bank de 9 a 9 1/8.
Par contre la Daira continue a reactionner de 28 13/16 a 28 11/16.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report.
div.p: Liverpool, May 25.

There has been a moderate business doing in Egyptian Cotton during the past week ; the demand, however, is freely supplied, and quotations are unchanged. Futures have been fairly active and the following are the latest values :––

American Futures. The Market this week has displayed considerable activity, and prices have advanced sharply ; to-day's closing values being 13 @ 15 points higher than those of last Thursday. The advance has been chiefly due to the continuance of extremely unfavorable weather reports, fears of overflows, and the lateness of the crop. There has been extensive covering by "Bears," and some "Bull" manipulation, apparently justified by the critical conditions over large areas still unplanted or requiring replanting. With prices, however, now in the neighborhood of 4 ½ d. per lb. we are inclined to think the market may pause, and that there may even be some healthy reaction, which we think should be taken advantage of to purchase in weak moments, for we should not be surprised to see prices higher up later on.
The following prices are the latest quotations.

div.head: EGYPTIAN WIZARDRY.
BY ANDREW LANG.
div.p: Moses, we know, was learned in all the magic of Egypt, and, indeed, was confessedly a greater proficient than the Egyptians themselves when he was challenged. It is curious that, despite our large knowledge of the old Egyptian world, we know so little of their wizardry, while that little is so futile or "feotle." Incantations written on papyrus make the staple of it : all sorts of beings with outlandish names are conjured to produce effects, which certainly do not follow if you read the incantations now. Of old Egyptian arts in glamour or the productions of hallucinations we know next to nothing and the Egyptian conjurers of to-day not the rather inexplicable tricks exhibited by a few Indian and Malay jugglers.

An eminent French Egyptologist, M. Lefebure, publishes in "La Revue Africaine" (No. 257) an essay on "The Ink Mirror in Arab Magic." On the whole it cannot be said to contain much of novelty, though it is abundantly erudite. That the Arabs of old, like Izaak Walton, believed in what is called "telepathy," Mr. Lefebure proves. The Khalife Omar had a presentiment that one of his generals was in a tight place, and in a vision advised him to occupy a certain kopje. The general may have had the rather obvious idea, and in a spirit of Oriental compliment may have attributed it to an inspiration from the remote Commander-in-Chief. The poet El Bohtery said that he had passed part of night in regretting the absence of a friend, and that the friend sent a vision of himself, which is a poetic way of describing a dream.

To get such visions at will the Arabs make a boy look hard at a spot of ink placed in the palm of his hand and surrounded by lines, numerals, and names of saints or angels. Incense of a particular kind is burned, invocations are uttered, but all thse solemnities mere mise en scene, and, except so far as they impress the boy with a sense of solemn occasion, and help to concentrate his kittenish mind on his task, they have no effect in enabling him to see visions in the blot of ink. The blot itself is superfluous. I am acquainted with a lady who, in place of crystal gazing in a glass ball or jug of water, merely looks hard and close at the palm of your hand. She is not troubling herself about the lines on the palm and the astrological nonsense connected with these natural depressions and elevations. She merely fixes her gaze on the palm till it vanishes from her conscious view and pictures take its place. I had only one chance of an experiment with this lady, previously a stranger, and the picture represented me sitting in a kind of coach-house taking off the waterproof waders in which I had been fishing. For a year I could not remember to have taken off my waders in any such place as that described, but quite lately a memory of doing so on the banks of the Kennet in the May fly season came back to me. That was not a striking experiment, but it illustrates the kind of picture which some people can get by staring at anything you please, so long as it is the kind of point of gaze to which they are accustomed. The old magicians and the Arabs do not seem to know what is essential and what is not in their complicated ceremonials. They choose certain seasons of the moon or aspects of the stars ; they prefer very young gazers (and the young are apt either to see or to say they see things) ; they think highly of women about to be mothers as gazers, and of Negroes ; they insist on burning incense as eagerly as some of the clergy of Bishop Creighton did, and they are as keen as they on vestments of magical symbolism. But all this is frippery. Some people can see curious pictures when they fix their eyes on a glass ball, a spot of ink, or what they please. Most people cannot do so, and therefore do not believe that any others can.

Pliny tells us that in his time the Egyptians used vessels of stained silver, blackened probably, when they consulted their god, the dog Anubis : promising the gods a good dinner at the same time, as we learn from Graeco-Egyptian papyri. The gods and the dog had nothing to do with the matter; all depended on the gazer, who could see, or vowed that he could see, or was frankly incompetent, as might happen in each case. In "The Arabian Nights" a lady sees a human figure in the stone of a ring –– many people do –– and she thinks that it is "the geni, the slave of the ring," as in the case of Aladdin's ring. Persian novels tell of mirrors darkened with ink, and Leo Africanus of bowls full of water, into which drops of oil are poured, the idea being to obscure the natural reflective quality of mirrors or of water. Most of us, in making experiments, see only our own noses reflected.

Lane, the translator of the Arabian Nights, in his "Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians," is the author who is usually regarded as the earliest modern writer on Egyptian ink matters (1833-34). M. Lefebure quotes de Laborde (August, 1883) as earlier, but there was information in 1831, for Sir Walter Scott, then about to go on his last tour abroad, and heard recent tales of the magic mirror in Egypt, and was very eager to investigate the facts. He could have done so at Abbotsford as easily as in Egypt; under the Eildons as readily as under the Pyramids. But he thought, like other people, that there was something peculiar in this Egyptian magic, though he had written of the same phenomena precisely in "My Aunt Margaret's Mirror" in Scotland, and of the mirror vision of fair Geraldine shown to Surrey in England. It is always the same story. An Australian black fellow, a wirreenun, or magician, told to a friend of mine the story of his magical initation and education. The elders caught him while he was a young boy, the favorite subject of the Egyptian enchanters.

A mysterious figures gave him a gubberah, or magic stone, "about the size and something of the shape of a small lemon, looking like a smooth lump of semi-transparent crystal. In such stones the wi-wirreenuns, or cleverest wizards, see visions of the past, of what is happening in the present at a distance, and of the future." I have a photograph of such a stone, polished and egg-shaped, like one with which I have seen the most futile of professional mediums make inefficient efforts to see visions. He said he saw "confusions," and was apparently too honest for his trade.

De Laborde began his study of Egyptian ink mirrors in 1827 with Lord Prudhoe, through whom the stories probably reached Scott ; if I mistake not they were published in the Quarterly Review, then edited by Lockhart. The first boy who was tried uttered a loud yell, and said that he saw something too frightful for description. The next boy was a jolly little fellow who went gaily to work, and saw what he was expected to see, a green-clad Sultan with a black beard, riding a white horse. That boy probably "had been there before," but he seemed very candid, and much interested. The magician was an Algerian Arab. He invited de Laborde and Lord Prudhoe to mention the people whom they wished the boy to see, an illegitimate method of proceeding. The question ought to be asked mentally, of course. Shakespeare was called for, but Bacon did not appear. The boy saw the conventional Shakespeare of the effigy and portrait. Many other persons probably unknown to the boy appeared in the mirror, and though there was a good deal of "irregularity," "the successes always left on us a profound impression." At last the boy seemed intoxicated, and convulsed, so the experimentes ended. "He gradually recovered, was gay , delighted with what he had seen, and pleased to tell his experiences."

The Arab sold "the secret" (that is, the formulae written on the boy's hand) for thirty piastres to de Laborde. A couple of squares, one within the other; a round blot of ink in the centre, and some numerals, amounting to 15 in whatever line you add them up, are all the thirty piastres worth. The reader may have them without extra charge.

The incantations are not given, but they do not count. De Laborde tried the experiment on a boy next day "with much success, and all the emotion which the gift of so strange a power could excite." He made experiments as conclusive on board ship and at Cairo and Alexandria. There are many formulae more elaborate than that of de Laborde, but the one thing essential is the gazing point, the blot of ink in the centre of the palm or of the square of paper, and even that, though useful, is not absolutely essential. (The Morning Post.)

div.head: UNITED STATES AND CHINA.
div.p: China threatens to boycott all American goods. Unless the United States Government modifies its policy of excluding Chinese from its territory Chinese merchants will refuse to buy from America, whose trade with China is second only to that of Great Britain. This boycott of American goods will be to the advantage of Great Britain and Japan.

div.head: EXCELLENT GERMANY!
div.p: Life in Germany has little resemblance to life in England. Germany is not a country that exists for the amusement of wrangling political parties, and the fate of its boys does not depend on the whims of a beautiful talker like Mr. Balfour, or even of a man of settled but ancient principles like Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman. In Germany the business of the Government is to do the best for nation, not according to the popularity of speakers with their own faction, but according to knowledge.
––"Morning Post."

div.head: THE MARRIAGE OF OXFORD DONS.
div.p: St. John's College, Oxford, has been amending its rules as regards the marriage of its Fellows. Under the old regime a man elected to an official fellowship forfeited it if he married within seven years of his election, as it was considered essential that four of the official Fellows should reside in college. But after this term of probation was passed he was free to marry.

By the new rule further obstacles are put in the way of matrimony. Now after the term of probation is passed, the official Fellow has still to go through the ordeal of applying to a general meeting of President and Fellows for leave to retain his fellowship after marriage ; and, of course, they may refuse to grant the application.

div.head: THE SMITHS AND THEIR RIVALS.
div.p: The fact that the name Smith occupies the largest space in English directories is indicative, says the "Manchester Guardian," of the broad basis from which our present metalworking industries began to develop, when Thomas the Smith and John the Smith were smiths indeed. On the Continent –– as, indeed, the history of the crafts of the various nations would lead us to expect –– this indication is not so marked. Although the Berlin directory registers some 5,000 Schmidts, yet the Schlutzes and Mullers are more numerous. The Jansen family is the largest of all in Brussels, and in the Paris directory that of Marinet. In Naples the names Morelli and Vitelli run one another very closely for precendence. Taking a line round the world, however, Smith is the most familiar name. Like the word "Hullo!" it crops up everywhere.

div.head: THE SUDAN AND ABYSSINIAN RAILWAYS
div.p: The negotiations which have centred round the proposal for the extension of the Djibouti-Harrar railway to Addis Abeba, the southern capital of Abyssinia, have been conducted primarily with a view to the preservation of the independence of that country, a matter of great concern to the rulers of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. Under the powerful sway of the present Negus, Menelik II., that independence is assured, but hitherto the death of the Negus has been followed almost invariably by civil war and a state of anarchy which afforded an opening for interference in the part of many neighbouring nations, as in the case of Egyptian encorachments in 1874-5. It is the object of each of the Powers interested, France, Italy, and Great Britain, to secure from the others a sort of self-denying ordinance in the event of such a crisis recurring. Great Britain, in its frontier arrangements with Menelik, has shown the utmost friendliness towards Abyssinia, and is a strong supporter of its independence. The other Powers are now equally ready to give assurances of their wish to prserve the existing condition of affairs, and, largely as a result of the cordial understanding between France and England, a question which has vexed the French Chambers considerably is on the point reaching a satisfactory settlement. The Abyssinians will be left to work out their own political future.

In the commercial development of the country France will reap the reward of its enterprise in having been the first to give Southern Abyssinia speedy and safe transit for its merchandise to a Red Sea port. Great Britain will not, for some years at least, build any competing line through British Somaliland to Harrar. The railway, if built, would be a strong competitor with the Djibouti line, and one would probably ruin the other; for at present there is no likelihood of suffcient trade to make two lines pay. Beyond Harrar the existing French-owned and Government subsidised line will be continued to Adis Abeba, a distance of some 250 miles. The engineering difficulties in running a line across the Abyssinian highlands are considerable, and it is anticipated that three years will be taken to build the line, which will be "internationalised" by the employment of the British and Italian as well as French capital in its construction.

This line, it is hoped, will be linked eventually with the Sudan railways. As long ago as May, 1902, Great Britain obtained the consent of the Negus Menelik to allow the construction through Abyssinian territory, of a railway to connect the Sudan with Uganda. Such a railway will take several years to complete, but the first section is likely to be put in hand directly on the completion of the Berber-Suakin line, which is expected to be open for traffic next year. The Sudan-Uganda line will start from Khartoum and descend along the valley of the Blue Nile, along one of the most fertile districts in the Sudan, a potentially great wheat and cotton-growing region. The Blue Nile being only navigable for a few months of the year, the development of this province is greatly retarded, and the construction of a railway as far as Roseires, 426 miles from Khartoum, has already obtained Lord Cromer's approval. Nothing further has been decided upon, and Roseires is 800 miles from the terminus of the Uganda Railway on Victoria Nyanza. It is, however, not more than 400 miles from Addis Abeba. Between the two places is the district of Beni Shangul (just within the Abyssinian frontier) which is known to be rich in gold, though in the absence of easy means of communication mining is impossible. In view of the future industrial development, both of the Sudan and Egypt, the Negus gives his consent to the extension of the Abyssinian lines to the Nile, and it will form an important link in the Cape-to-Cairo scheme.

div.head: THE IDEAL HUSBAND
div.p: Lady St. Helier writes on the "Ideal Husband" in the June number of "Leisure Hour." The real ideal husband, her ladyship says, should be a busy man, and one whose day is very full. Men are not happy without plenty of work ; and a man who has no outlet for his energy elsewhere bestows it on his household, with generally unfavourable results. Small household concerns are not a man's business, and nothing is more irritating than the perpetual interference of a theorist in the small matters of life. In plenty of occupation is the real secret of happiness, but the woman must be content to take the smaller share in the wider and more engrossing life of the man she lives with.

In the wider lives that women now lead, it appears as if little of the hardships and equalities of which they complained had survived, and in the generous acceptance of that new position by men lies the fundamental reason for the happiness which we believe exists in England in as great a measure as anywhere.

The ideal husband, continues Lady St. Helier, if he is a senbiel one, will not forget the small signs of affection which constitute such a real joy in the lives of many women. Many a married life has been wrecked by the neglect of these small attentions so dear to the heart of women, but to which men pay so little heed and attach so little value. It is not that the sense of affection on the husband's part has diminished, but the fulness of his life and his business occupations absorb his thoughts, and the wife should content herself with such evidences of tenderness as he, harassed and busy, can find time to bestow, and the value of which is no less than the warmest feelings of their earlier married life.

One does not intend to convey the idea that the absence of these little courtesies on the husband's part betokens the depature of affection ; for the real affection, which is the only sure foundation on which happy married life is built, remains, and is stronger and safer than the more demonstrative love of youth. The real friendship which grows up between husband and wife is the best and surest guarantee of happiness, and though something of the sentiment, romance, and passion have disappeared, the realities remain on which real and lasting happiness depends.

div.head: JAPANESE IN AMERICA.
div.p: Labor unions in California greatly resent the immigration of Japanese into the United States, and have formed an anti-Japanese league to fight what is termed the "Yellow Peril." At a mass meeting in San Francisco a speaker declared that California "was confronted with the greatest monster that has ever threatened to invade her shores –– the yellow peril. The Japanese bid fair to overrun our land within a comparatively few years. They will monopolise us if we sit idly and allow them to pour in by thousands.

"Making a comparatively light estimate of the number of Japanese in the United States to-day, I will venture to say that there are at least 59,000 of them, and the same number in the Hawaiian Islands. They are coming over at the rate of 500 and 1,000 a steamer since the Japanese Government lately refused to place any restriction on emigration from the country.

"The American workman is not afraid of the Japanese in honest competition of labour, but he cannot work like them, neither can he afford to work for the wages they ask. Therefore it means extinction to him if the yellow pests continue to overflow the country. They will ruin us if they get the chance, and even now they threaten the existence of our nation."

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
Emission d'Actions en augmentation du Capital Social
div.p: En verte d'une deliberation de l'Assemblee Generale Extraordinaire du 24 Mai 1905, le Conseil d'Administration de la NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, met en souscription cinquante mille actions nouvelles de la dite Banque, de dix livres sterling chacune, creees en augmentation du Capital Social, conformement aux Statuts, et emises aux conditions ci-apres.
L'emission est faite au prix de 20 livres sterling l'action payable comme suit :
Tout retard dans les versements donnera lieu a l'application des dispositions des articles 12 et 13 des Statuts.
EN EGYPTE: au Siege Social, au Caire, et a la Succursale d'Alexandrie.
A LONDRES: a l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5 King William Street.
Les nouvelles actions participeront aux benefices a partir du 1er Janvier 1906, c'est-a-dire a partir du prochain exercice.

Tout porteur d'actions anciennes a du chef des actions par lui possedees un droit de preference a la souscription d'une action nouvelle pour cing actions anciennes sans attribution de fractions. Les actions non souscrities en vertu de ce droit de preference seront attribuees a la souscription publique.

Les porteurs d'actions anciennes qui voudront exercer leur droit de preference devront d'ici au 8 Juin 1905 inclusivement, a peine de decheance, faire leur souscription de ce chef aux endroits oi lessus designes avec depot des titres par eux possedes et versement du montant du premier terme de £2.10/ par action.

Les actions nou souscrites par les actionnaires en vertu de leur droit de preference sont offertes a la souscription publique. Les actionnaires qui independeamment des actions par eux souscrites en vertu de leur droit de preference, vondraient prendre part a la souscription publique, devront, de ce deruier chef, remplir la formule de souscription speciale a cet effet.
La souscription sera close, tant pour les actionnaires que pour le public, le 8 juin a midi et demi.
ELWIN PALMER.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
AVIS
div.p: La Societe des Eaux du Caire porte a la connaissance du Public, que son installation pour la distribution des Eaux a Koubbeh Zeitoun et Matarieh etant achevee, elle est prete a fournir dans les dites localites, l'eau pour la consommation, arrosage des jardins, chantiers de constructions et tous autres besoins.
Toute demande de concession devra etre faite par lettre a l'adresse du Directeur de la Societe des Eaux de Caire.
Le tarif du prix de l'eau dans les dites localites, tant par abonnement fixe que par compteur, est a la disposition du public, dans les Bureaux de la Societe Avenue de Boulac au Caire.

La Societe est prete a etablir ses canalisations d'eau dans les rues non pourvues de conduites, lorsqu'elle aura recu des demandes suffisantes de concession pour une meme rue. ––Les habitants de Koubbeh, Zeitoun, et Matarieh sont done pries de presenter leur demandes par groupes reidant dans une meme rue, afin de permettre a la Societe d'examiner sans retard leurs demandes, en vue de canaliser et de leur accorder des concessions d'eau.
Le Caire, le 23 Janvier 1905.
Le Directeur,
25329-40*-22 Astley P. Friend.
